Lots of non-human animals owe their distinctive looks, as well as their names,
to piebaldism, like the magpie, and the bald eagle.
In these and other animals, pibaldism manifests itself as patches of hair or feathers that lack pigmentation
while the rest of the animal has some coloration.
But the term also applies to humans, in whom piebaldism can create patches of unpigmented skin and hair.
One of the most common effects is a lack of coloration in a lock of hair at the front of the hairline.
This is known as a white forelock.

Scientists aren't exactly sure what causes it, but erythrism seems to be the result of a recessive gene
that causes either too much of red pigment, or too little of other colors.

But what's perplexing is how such a trait could be inheritable in animals in the wild.

The yellow gentian plant, known as gentiana lutea, is native to Europe, and all the plant is extremely bitter, not just the root.
Because the plant is rich in a compound known as amarogentin, a chemical that's 300 times as bitter as pure quinine.
And by one estimate, a mixture of 1 part amarogentin to 200000 parts water would be undrinkable.
So the dash of bitters you put in your Manhattan has gentian root in it, but a lot less than that.
By comparison, wormood, the main ingredient in absinthe, is probably the second bitterest substance,
thanks to a glucoside compound known as absinthin.
